fr:mainmatter.html:p: In previous lectures, we have seen two apparently different ways to generate a class of formal languages: by means of regular expressions and by means of finite automata. The goal of this lecture is to see that all these classes of language coincide, which is a theorem due to Stephen Kleene; to start with, we define regular languages below.
A formal language is called regular if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for some regular expression R.
Using a bit of non-standard terminology, we give a name to the class of languages that can be recognised by finite automata.
A formal language is called automatical if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} for some finite automaton M.
By virtue of Corollary , it does not matter at all whether Definition is understood to be referring to DFAs, NFA, or NFA\varepsilon s: the conditions are all equivalent.

fr:title.text: Lecture 23: regular languages and Kleene’s theorem

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lecture 23: regular languages and Kleene’s theorem

fr:mainmatter.html:p: These lecture notes were prepared by Jon Sterling by adapting prior notes created by Andrew Pitts that I inherited from Frank Stajano.

In previous lectures, we have seen two apparently different ways to generate a class of formal languages: by means of regular expressions and by means of finite automata. The goal of this lecture is to see that all these classes of language coincide, which is a theorem due to Stephen Kleene; to start with, we define regular languages below.
A formal language is called regular if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for some regular expression R.
Using a bit of non-standard terminology, we give a name to the class of languages that can be recognised by finite automata.
A formal language is called automatical if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} for some finite automaton M.
By virtue of Corollary , it does not matter at all whether Definition is understood to be referring to DFAs, NFA, or NFA\varepsilon s: the conditions are all equivalent.

When we wanted to show that different kinds of automata generated the same class of languages, we first described a method to convert between them: in particular, the subset construction converts an NFA\varepsilon to a DFA that accepts the same language, as we proved in Corollary . Today, we will use a similar strategy: we will show in § how to compile a regular expression to an NFA accepting the same language, and vice versa in [jms-017Z]; from this we will conclude Kleene’s theorem, which states that a language is regular if and only if it is automatical.

fr:title.text: Compiling a regular expression to an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Compiling a regular expression to an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We aim to show that every regular language is automatical. The rule induction principle for regular expressions implies that the regular languages are the smallest class of formal languages closed under unions, concatenation, repetition, single symbols, the empty string, and the empty language. Therefore, to prove our desired theorem it will suffice to show that the automatical languages are closed under the same constructions.

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. Then the basic regular languages {\mathopen {}\left \{a\right \}\mathclose {}} = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (a\right )\mathclose {}} for a\in \Sigma , and {\mathopen {}\left \{\epsilon \right \}\mathclose {}} = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\underline {\epsilon }\right )\mathclose {}}, and \varnothing = \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\varnothing \right )\mathclose {}} are all automatical.
For the symbol a\in \Sigma , we choose the following very simple DFA:
For the empty string, we have a simple NFA with no transitions at all (this would be an example of where the corresponding DFA would be somewhat unnatural):
For the empty language, we have the following NFA with no accepting states:
If L_1 and L_2 are automatical languages over a common alphabet \Sigma , then so is their union L_1\cup L_2.

Let M_1 and M_2 be finite automata with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}}=L_i; without loss of generality, we assume these have disjoint sets of states. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}}.
We define an accepting state of M above to be either an accepting state of M_1 or of M_2. F_{M} = F_{M_1}\cup F_{M_2}

That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds follows by a quick inspection: indeed, if u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}} then we have a path in M_i from \star {M_i} to an accepting state in M_i, which we can extend by means of either \varepsilon -transition to a path in M. Conversely, any from q_0 to an accepting state of M must either be a path to an accepting state of some M_i and must therefore pass through one of the two \varepsilon -transitions. Chop off that transition to get a valid path in either M_1 or M_2.
That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds by inspection.
If L_1 and L_2 are automatical languages over a common alphabet \Sigma , then so is their concatenation L_1L_2, which we defined below:

Let M_1 and M_2 be finite automata with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_i\right )\mathclose {}}=L_i; without loss of generality, we assume that these have disjoint sets of states. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}}; in particular, we lay out M_1 and M_2 side by side and draw an \varepsilon -transition from every accepting node of M_1 to the staring node of M_2.
The starting node of M is that of M_1 and the accepting nodes of M are those of M_2.
That \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_1\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M_2\right )\mathclose {}} holds by inspection.
If L is an automatical language over a given alphabet \Sigma , then so is the repetition L^\star of L, which we define below in terms of concatenation:

Let M be a finite automaton with \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=L. We shall describe an NFA\varepsilon M^\star satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M^\star \right )\mathclose {}}=L^\star ; we take M and add a new starting state q_0 with an \varepsilon -transition to the old starting state, and then we make an \epsilon -transition from every old accepting state back to q_0.
The only accepting state of M^\star is q_0.
It holds by inspection that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M^\star \right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}^\star .
If a language L is regular, then it is automatical.

Let U be the set of all regular expressions R over a fixed alphabet \Sigma such that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical. We wish to show that the set of all regular expressions over \Sigma is contained in U. By rule induction it suffices to check the following cases:

html:ol.html:li: We need to know that \texttt {Sym}_{a},\texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never} \in U, which is the same as to say that the languages {\mathopen {}\left \{a\right \}\mathclose {}}, {\mathopen {}\left \{\epsilon \right \}\mathclose {}}, \varnothing are all automatical. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R,S\in U then \texttt {Union}{\mathopen {}\left (R,S\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that the language \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\cup \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical assuming that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} and \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} are. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R,S\in U then \texttt {Concat}{\mathopen {}\left (R,S\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that the language \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{uv\,\middle \vert \,u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}},v\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\right \}\mathclose {}} is automatical assuming that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} and \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} are. This is Lemma .

We need to show that if R\in U then so is \texttt {Star}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\in U, which is to say that if \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} is automatical then so is \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}^\star . This is Lemma .

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We are done.

fr:title.text: Decompiling a regular expression from an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Decompiling a regular expression from an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We want to “decompile” any NFA to an equivalent regular expression; it is not easy to do so directly, so we will actually solve a more general problem first.
Let M be an NFA. A region of M is defined to be a triple {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} with S\subseteq Q_{M} and q,q'\in Q_{M}.

A region {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} in an NFA M is meant to encode a language whose strings consist of those that can be consumed starting from states q and ending in state q' passing only through states that lie in S. We define this more formally below.

fr:title.text: The formal language accepted within a region

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted within a region

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} be a region in an NFA M. The formal language accepted within {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} is defined to be the following set of strings:
We shall also refer to \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} as the regional language of M in {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}}.
Any regional language of an NFA is regular.
We proceed by induction on the number of elements in S.

In the base case, we know that S is empty; the regional language \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,\varnothing ,q'\right )\mathclose {}} therefore consist of those strings u such that either u=\epsilon and q=q', or u=a for some a\in \Sigma _M and q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'. Writing this more formally, we have:
The above is a finite union of regular languages, and so it is evidently regular.

In the inductive step, we assume that any regional language whose interior state set has n elements is regular, and we must show the same for any regional language whose interior state set has n+1 elements. Fixing such a region {\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} with \#S=n+1, we will try to reduce the \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}} to something in terms languages that we know by our inductive hypothesis to be regular. Our strategy is to simply remove an arbitrary element from S.

To that end, we pick some arbitrary q_0\in S so that the set difference S' = S\setminus {\mathopen {}\left \{q_0\right \}\mathclose {}} has n elements. IF we think about all the ways taht we could get from q to q' passing through states lying only in S, there are a two possibilities in relation to the state q_0:

html:ol.html:li: We might have never pass through q_0 at all. This would correspond to the regional language \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S',q'\right )\mathclose {}}, which we know to be regular by our induction hypothesis.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We see the following by inspection:
As regular languages are closed under finite unions, we are done.
Any automatical language is regular.

We have shown in Lemma that each regional langauge of an NFA is regular; regular languages are closed under finite unions, so it suffices to decompose \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} into a finite union of regional languages \mathcal {L}_{M}{\mathopen {}\left (q,S,q'\right )\mathclose {}}.

We note that if a string is accepted by M, it does so by means of a path from the starting state to some accepting state; each of these scenarios for a given accepting state specifies a region {\mathopen {}\left (s_{M},Q_{M},q\right )\mathclose {}} with q\in F_{M}. Therefore, we immediately deduce:
Therefore it follows that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is regular.
We now come to the main result of this lecture.
A formal language is regular if and only if it is automatical.
By Corollary and Corollary .

In light of the above, we will from now on refer mainly to regular languages, and leave behind the non-standard terminology of “automatical languages”. Several questions that we left unanswered (see Discussion ) can now be addressed in light of Kleene’s theorem.
Let R be a regular expression over an alphabet \Sigma . Then there exists an algorithm to compute whether a given string u\in \Sigma ^\star matches R.

The idea of the proof is to find a DFA M satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}; so for this we need only Corollary rather than the full Kleene’s theorem. Then our algorithm is to feed the given string u through M and check whether the final state is accepting or not.

There is a subtlety in the argument above: we need the DFA M to have computably decidable equality of states. The way to deal with this is that M has a finite set of states, and so isomorphic to a standard finite set of the form \mathbb {N}_{<n}, which has computably decidable equality. A more important subtlety is that we need it to be computably decidable whether a given state is an accepting state, and we also need the transition function to be computable; any subset of a finite set is going to be decidable for roughly the same reason—ahead of time, we can enumerate it as a list of numbers in \mathbb {N}_{<n}.

fr:title.text: Closure of regular languages under complementation

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of regular languages under complementation

fr:mainmatter.html:p: If L is a regular language over an alphabet \Sigma , then so is its complement \Sigma ^\star \setminus L.

Let L be a regular language, and so by Kleene’s theorem we have some DFA M satisfying L=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}. We define a new DFA \lnot {M} satisfying \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\lnot {M}\right )\mathclose {}} = \Sigma ^\star \setminus L by setting \lnot {M} to have the same states, transition function, and starting state as M but with the opposite set of accepting states:
The desired property of \lnot {M} is immediate.

fr:title.text: Closure of regular languages under intersection

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Closure of regular languages under intersection

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The intersection of two regular languages over a fixed alphabet \Sigma is regular.
We fix regular languages L_1,L_2\subseteq \Sigma ^\star and consider the intersection L_1\cap L_2. By De Morgan’s laws, we have:

Because regular languages are closed under complementation, it suffices to check that {\mathopen {}\left ( \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_1 \right )\mathclose {}}\cup {\mathopen {}\left ( \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_2 \right )\mathclose {}} is regular. Regular languages are, by definition, closed under finite unions, so it remains to check that the complements \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_1 and \Sigma ^\star \setminus L_2 are regular. This follows from our assumption that L_1 and L_2 are regular via closure under complements.

It is decidable whether two regular expressions R,S over a fixed alphabet \Sigma are equivalent in the sense that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}.
We note that two subsets are equal if and only if the intersection of one with the complement of the other is empty, and vice versa:

We therefore let M and N be two DFAs recognising the language {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ^\star \setminus \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\cap \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} and {\mathopen {}\left (\Sigma ^\star \setminus \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\cap \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} respectively. (These DFAs can be obtained computably using the compilation procedure by which we proved Corollary .) It follows then that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (S\right )\mathclose {}} if and only if \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}=\varnothing =\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (N\right )\mathclose {}}.

So it now remains to check whether there exists any string at all that is accepted by M and likewise for N. We do not have to check all strings over \Sigma , which would be impossible: we observe that the number of states in M bounds the number of transitions required to reach an accepting state, because any loops about a state q can be excised from the path without changing the result. This is a special property of the finite automata that we have studied so far, corresponding to the fact that they have no memory.
A formal language is called automatical if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} for some finite automaton M.
A formal language is called regular if it is equal to \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for some regular expression R.

fr:title.text: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs all generate the same class of languages.

In Lemma and Lemma , we have proved that NFA\varepsilon s and DFAs generate the same class of language as any NFA\varepsilon can be converted into a DFA recognising the same language. As any NFA is in particular an NFA\varepsilon , we see that NFAs are equivalent to DFAs in the same sense.

A non-deterministic finite automaton with \varepsilon -transitions or NFA\varepsilon for short is an NFA M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} together with an additional relation T\colon Q\mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the \varepsilon -transition relation.

We will write q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' to mean that q\mathrel {T}q'. This notation is a little confusing! Note that this \varepsilon is not the same as the \epsilon denoting the empty string, and that therefore q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' means something very different from q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}\smash {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}^*} q'.

A deterministic finite automaton or DFA for short is an NFA for which the transition relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q is a function, i.e. a total and functional relation. This states, in other words, that to each state each state q\in Q can transition along each symbol a\in \Sigma to one and only one state, which we conventionally write \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}. Indeed, we will often write M = (Q,\Sigma ,\delta ,s,F) for a DFA. In this case, we have q \mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q' if and only if \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}=q'.

As an aside, it might feel strange to speak of “deterministic non-deterministic finite automata”. This is OK but can take some getting used to: mathematicians have discovered over the past several centuries that it is better for negations in terminology to mean “not necessarily” rather than “definitely not”; this is similar to the way that mathematicians often say “greater than” to mean “greater than or equal to”, reserving “strictly greater than” for the notion that excludes equality.
A non-deterministic finite automaton or NFA for short is defined to be a tuple M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} where:

html:ol.html:li: Q is a finite set (of “states”).
\Sigma is an alphabet, i.e. a finite set.
\Delta is a ternary relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the transition relation: we write q\xrightarrow {a}{q'} to mean that (q,a,q')\in \Delta .
s is an element of Q, the “starting state”.
F is a subset of Q, the “accepting states”.

fr:title.text: Lecture 21: regular expressions and pattern matching

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Lecture 21: regular expressions and pattern matching

fr:mainmatter.html:p: These lecture notes were prepared by Jon Sterling by adapting prior notes created by Andrew Pitts that I inherited from Frank Stajano.
Syntax comes in two forms: there is concrete syntax, and this is what people are talking about when they say things like:
fr:mainmatter.html:blockquote: I prefer the syntax of Rust to C++.
I (can’t stand, love) the way that Haskell and Python have indentation-sensitive syntax.
fr:mainmatter.html:p: Concrete syntax is usually defined in terms of strings of symbols. In general, concrete syntax may use a variety of tools (including brackets, whitespace, etc.) to disambiguiate what would not be ambiguous in a structured representation, e.g. as a syntax tree. The structured representation of syntax as trees or a similar data structure (like a directed acyclic graph) is called abstract syntax. The process of converting concrete syntax to abstract syntax is called parsing.
Here is an example of concrete syntax, in the OCaml language:

The OCaml parser then converts this into a tree, with vertices labelled by syntactic forms and subtrees given by arguments. Parenthesisation and operator precedence is now replaced by the parent-child relationship.

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage {forest,libertine}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Using the tools that we have built up in Lecture 20, we can smoothly study both concrete and abstract syntax. Somewhat confusingly, our running example will be the language of regular expressions (this might be confusing because regular expressions are a streamlined way to present the grammar of certain kinds of formal languages—but we are treating the grammar of regular expressions themselves).

Let \Sigma be an alphabet. We then let \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}} be the disjoint union of \Sigma with the set {\mathopen {}\left \{\underline {\epsilon },\varnothing , \vert ,*,(,)\right \}\mathclose {}}. Then a concrete syntax of regular expressions over \Sigma can be defined as a formal language over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}, which we present by means of the following syntactic rules:

Above we let a range over \Sigma and r,s range over \Sigma _{\mathsf {rx}}^\star . We are careful to distinguish the formal symbol \underline {\epsilon } from \epsilon : \epsilon is literally the empty string, whereas \underline {\epsilon } is the symbol representing the regular expression that matches the empty string!

fr:title.text: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Derivation of a concrete regular expression

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The (concrete) regular expression \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab* can be derived in the formal language presented in Definition as follows:

The abstract syntax of regular expressions over an alphabet \Sigma will be represented by trees whose vertices are labelled by the symbols \texttt {Union}, \texttt {Concat}, \texttt {Star}, \texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never}, and \texttt {Sym}_{a} for any a\in \Sigma . More specifically, each node of a tree will be of the following form:

html:ol.html:li: A node labelled by either \texttt {Union} or \texttt {Concat} has exactly two children.
A node labelled by \texttt {Star} has exactly one child.
A node labelled by \texttt {Null}, \texttt {Never}, or \texttt {Sym}_{a} has no children.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The plain English description above could be expressed as an inductive definition of a subset of the set of all trees.
We recall the derivation for the concrete regular expression \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab*. This will correspond eventually to the following abstract syntax tree as specified by Definition :

fr:resource.fr:resource-source: \usepackage {forest}\usepackage [tt=false]{libertine}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Observe that we had to decide whether how tightly the concatenation and union operators bind with respect to each other. That is part of defining the parsing relation.

Parsing is decribed by a relation from concrete syntax to abstract syntax. Ideally, this relation would be functional and so give rise to a partial function. In order to achieve this, we address ahead of time any ambiguity in how tightly operators bind: for example, ab\vert c should be the union of ab and c, rather than the concatenation of a with b\vert c.

This can be achieved by defining a more complex three-place relation {r} \leadsto {R} \mathrel {@} {n} on concrete syntax r, abstract syntax R, and precedences n. The idea is that we parse operations in the order of increasing tightness/precedence: in this case, that will be \texttt {Union} followed by \texttt {Concat} followed by \texttt {Star} followed by all the atomic regular expressions: \texttt {Sym}_{a}, \texttt {Null}, and \texttt {Never}.
If we are parsing, e.g., unions but we encounter only a symbol, that needs to be allowed too. So we add a rule that coerces a higher precedence to a lower one silently:
Finally, we allow the use of parentheses to coerce a precedences in the other direction; this is what would make it possible to concatenate a union with another regular expression.

We then define the parsing relation {r}\leadsto {R} to hold if and only if {r} \leadsto {R} \mathrel {@} {0} holds. We demonstrate parsing derivation for \underline {\epsilon }\vert ab* and (\underline {\epsilon }\vert a)b* as follows:

We have seen the syntax of regular expressions in both concrete and abstract form. What about semantics, i.e. what do regular expressions actually do? The meaning of a given regular expression over an alphabet \Sigma is a matching predicate on strings over \Sigma that says when a given string is matched by the regular expression. In this course, we are particularly interested in the class of formal languages that can be recognised by regular expressions, and later on we will develop tools that allow us to show that some formal languages are too complex to be recognised by regular expressions. In the meanwhile, we will first explain how matching works.

fr:title.text: The matching relation for regular expressions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The matching relation for regular expressions

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The matching relation u\mathrel {\textsf {matches}}R is given by an inductive definition over \Sigma ^\star \times \mathsf {Regexp}_{\Sigma }.
We will write \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (R\right )\mathclose {}} for the formal language matching or “recognised” by the regular expression R:

We can also obtain a version of the matching relation between strings over \Sigma and concrete regular expressions by relational composition with the (transpose of) the parsing relation. Alternatively, we can simply write the concrete syntax as a mere notation (to be eliminated by the reader immediately) for the abstract syntax. In fact, that is what we will do in the future.
Consider regular expression matching over the alphabet \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}.

html:ol.html:li: a\vert b is matched by each symbol in \Sigma .
(a\vert b)* is matched every string over \Sigma .
b(a\vert b)* is matched by any string over \Sigma that starts with a b.
((a\vert b)(a\vert b))* is matched by any string of even length over \Sigma .
(\underline {\epsilon }\vert a)(\underline {\epsilon }\vert b)\vert bb is matched just by the strings \epsilon , a, b, ab, and bb.
\varnothing b\vert a is matched only by the symbol a.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Here are some questions for discussion.

html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r?
In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern?
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language?
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression?

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We will come back to these questions in subsequent lectures. In the meantime, we can say:

html:ol.html:li: Is there an algorithm which, given a string u and a regular expression r, computes whether or not u matches r? Yes. One very simple way is to simply use the rules of Definition as a search algorithm, but this is not very efficient; better ways to decide regular expression matching can be achieved using finite automata, which we will study in the next lecture.

In formulating the definition of regular expressions, have we missed out on some practically useful notions of pattern? Yes! For example, it can be useful to specify a range of symbols (including all symbols!) over an alphabet like most practical regular expression libraries allow. A more sophisticated example is complementation, where a string matches \mathord {\sim }(r) if and only if it does not match r. We will ultimately see that the complement of any regular expression already exists—but it can be useful to include it as a built-in feature.
Is there an algorithm that will compute whether two regular expressions generate the same language? Yes, but we will need the theory of finite automata to see that this is the case.
Is every formal language of generated by a regular expression? No: we will ultimately learn a technique, called the pumping lemma to find counter-examples.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: A formal language over an alphabet \Sigma is defined to be a subset of \Sigma ^\star , i.e. a set of strings over \Sigma .
These lecture notes were prepared by Jon Sterling by adapting prior notes created by Andrew Pitts that I inherited from Frank Stajano.
In this lecture, we introduce our a fundamental mathematical model of computatation: the finite automaton.
The most basic form of automaton is the non-deterministic finite automaton as defined below.
A non-deterministic finite automaton or NFA for short is defined to be a tuple M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} where:

html:ol.html:li: Q is a finite set (of “states”).
\Sigma is an alphabet, i.e. a finite set.
\Delta is a ternary relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the transition relation: we write q\xrightarrow {a}{q'} to mean that (q,a,q')\in \Delta .
s is an element of Q, the “starting state”.
F is a subset of Q, the “accepting states”.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The idea of an NFA is that you “feed” it a string after initialising it to its starting state, and then you explore the transitions it makes by biting off characters from the string until it is consumed. If the automaton ends up in an accepting state then the string is accepted; otherwise, the string is considered rejected. More formally:

fr:title.text: The formal language accepted by an NFA

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted by an NFA

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M=(Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F) be a non-deterministic finite automaton over an alphabet \Sigma . Then the formal language accepted by M is defined to be the subset \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \Sigma ^\star specified as follows:
For the above, we define the relation q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {u}}\smash {\xrightarrow {u}}^*} q' by induction on the string u:
This is similar to reflexive-transitive closure in a directed graph, except that the edges of our graph are labelled by symbols from the alphabet \Sigma .

NFAs represent an extremely limited but nonetheless useful form of computational power; intuitively, this is because they don’t have any memory. It is therefore an interesting theorem when a language can be recognised by an NFA. In this lecture we will show that (1) NFAs can be given some more capabilities without changing the class of languages they recognise, and (2) the non-determinism of the transition relation is not necessary. Having more capabilities is helpful when constructing an automaton, but having fewer capabilities is helpful when investigating the class of all automata.

NFAs are usually drawn in a graphical notation that depicts the states as circled nodes, with possible transitions given by arrows between the nodes. The starting state is drawn with an arrow pointing from it out of nowhere, and the accepting states are drawn in double-struck circles. For example, consider the following picture:
The picture above depicts an NFA accepting the following formal language over the alphabet \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}:

Indeed, from the initial state we can consume as many as and bs as we like but at some point we must transition along an a to q_1 after which we have no choice but to consume two as until we reach an accepting state q_3. At this point, we can continue with as many as and bs as we like (an accepting state does not have to be a terminal state!).

A deterministic finite automaton or DFA for short is an NFA for which the transition relation \Delta \colon Q\times \Sigma \mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q is a function, i.e. a total and functional relation. This states, in other words, that to each state each state q\in Q can transition along each symbol a\in \Sigma to one and only one state, which we conventionally write \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}. Indeed, we will often write M = (Q,\Sigma ,\delta ,s,F) for a DFA. In this case, we have q \mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q' if and only if \delta {\mathopen {}\left (q,a\right )\mathclose {}}=q'.

As an aside, it might feel strange to speak of “deterministic non-deterministic finite automata”. This is OK but can take some getting used to: mathematicians have discovered over the past several centuries that it is better for negations in terminology to mean “not necessarily” rather than “definitely not”; this is similar to the way that mathematicians often say “greater than” to mean “greater than or equal to”, reserving “strictly greater than” for the notion that excludes equality.
An NFA can fail to be deterministic in just two ways:

html:ol.html:li: There could be a pair (q,a) for which there exists no transition q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'.
There could be a pair (q,a) such that q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q' and q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q'' for distinct states q',q''\in Q.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: We recall our sample NFA over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} from Example fails to be deterministic in both ways: we have both q_0\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q_0 and q_0\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a}}q_1, and moreover there is no transition along b from state q_1 and q_2.
We could make the automaton deterministic by removing some transitions and adding others, while still accepting the same language:

So the above is a DFA over \Sigma . But if were to view it as an NFA over the extended alphabet \Sigma ' = {\mathopen {}\left \{a,b,c\right \}\mathclose {}}, then it would again fail to be deterministic because there would be no transitions along c!

We will ultimately show that every NFA can be transformed into a more complicated DFA that accepts the same language. But before we do so, we introduce a further strengthening of the features of NFAs that can be reduced directly to DFAs in one go.

A non-deterministic finite automaton with \varepsilon -transitions or NFA\varepsilon for short is an NFA M = {\mathopen {}\left (Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F\right )\mathclose {}} together with an additional relation T\colon Q\mathbin {\nrightarrow } Q called the \varepsilon -transition relation.

We will write q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' to mean that q\mathrel {T}q'. This notation is a little confusing! Note that this \varepsilon is not the same as the \epsilon denoting the empty string, and that therefore q\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\varepsilon }}q' means something very different from q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}\smash {\xrightarrow {\epsilon }}^*} q'.
The purpose of the \varepsilon -transition relation in an NFA\varepsilon is to allow the automaton to transition to states without consuming a symbol.
The graphical notation of NFAs that we introduced in Example can be extended to handle \varepsilon -transitions in a straightforward way. For example:

In Definition we described the formal language accepted by an NFA in terms of a labelled path relation q\mathrel {\vphantom {\xrightarrow {u}}\smash {\xrightarrow {u}}^*} q'. Below, we give an analogous definition that accounts for \varepsilon -transitions.

fr:title.text: The formal language accepted by an NFA\varepsilon

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language accepted by an NFA\varepsilon

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Let M=(Q,\Sigma ,\Delta ,s,F,T) be an NFA\varepsilon . The formal lanuage accepted by M is defined to be the subset \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \Sigma ^\star specified as follows:

Above we define the relation q\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}} q' to mean that there exists a path through M from q to q' whose non-\varepsilon -transitions consume the string u. In more formal terms, we can define the relation inductively by rules:

fr:title.text: The formal language depicted in Example [https://www.jonmsterling.com/jms-017P/]

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The formal language depicted in Example

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Returning to the NFA\varepsilon depicted in Example in light of Definition , we see for example that we have paths q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {aa}}q_2, q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {aa}}q_3, and q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {bb}}q_7. Overall, the formal language of this NFA\varepsilon is that of the regular expression (a\vert b){*}(aa\vert bb)(a\vert b){*}.

We see from Example that the possibility of \varepsilon -transitions makes it much easier to design an automaton that corresponds to a given regular expression. This is one of the motivations adding this feature to NFAs, as we shall see in a subsequent lecture.

fr:title.text: The subset construction: equivalence of NFA\varepsilon s with DFAs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: The subset construction: equivalence of NFA\varepsilon s with DFAs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: Although very few NFA\varepsilon s are NFAs and very few of those are DFAs, all these kinds of automata nonetheless generate the same classes of formal languages. In the upward direction, it is easy to see that any DFA is also an NFA with a deterministic and total transition relation, and moreover any NFA is an NFA\varepsilon with an empty \varepsilon -transition relation, and that the formal languages induced by all these agree. Conversely, it is much less obvious that we can go the other direction, i.e. that we can associate to a given NFA\varepsilon an NFA or a DFA that accepts the same formal language. That is the purpose of the subset construction which we shall study in this section.
Let M be an NFA\varepsilon over an alphabet \Sigma ; we define an DFA \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} over \Sigma called the subset construction of M as follows:

html:ol.html:li: We define the set of states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} to be the powerset of the set of states of M. Q_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (Q_{M}\right )\mathclose {}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{S\,\middle \vert \,S\subseteq Q_{M}\right \}\mathclose {}}

The starting state of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is the set of states reachable by any number of \varepsilon -transitions from the starting state of M, i.e. the set of states reachable from s_{M} via the empty string: s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} = {\mathopen {}\left \{q\in Q\,\middle \vert \,s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q\right \}\mathclose {}}

fr:mainmatter.html:p: In order to get a thorough intuition for the subset construction we will see how it acts on a sample NFA\varepsilon M over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}} which we draw below:

html:figure.html:figcaption: A sample NFA\varepsilon M over \Sigma ={\mathopen {}\left \{a,b\right \}\mathclose {}}, where \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}={\mathopen {}\left \{a^mb^n\right \}\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (a{*}b{*}\right )\mathclose {}}.

fr:mainmatter.html:p: The states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} are all the subsets of Q_{M}:
The starting state of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} is the set of states reachable from q_0 via the empty string:
The accepting states of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} are all the sets of states containing an accepting state of M:
We then describe the transition function of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} by means of a table:
All in all, we have the following DFA:
As you can see, the resulting DFA is kind of strange and has many redundant states. But it does accept the desired language.

The goal of Definition is to transform an NFA\varepsilon M into a DFA \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} that accepts the same language, i.e. that \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}=\mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}. We prove this in two steps below.

Let M be an NFA\varepsilon ; then \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

We must show that any string u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

If u=\epsilon , then by definition we have s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} and so by definition, there exists q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} such that q\in F_{M}. By definition of s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, we therefore have s\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q; because q\in F_{M}, we have \epsilon \in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}.

Suppose on the other hand that u=a_1\cdots a_n, and so we therefore have transitions s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_1}}S_1\mathrel {\xrightarrow {\ldots }}S_{n-1}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_n}}S_n with S_n\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, and so there exists some q_n\in S_n\cap F_{M}. Define S_0 = s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}.

By definition of \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}, from the transition S_{n-1}\mathrel {\xrightarrow {a_n}}S_n we may find some q_{n-1}\in S_{n-1} such that q_{n-1}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {a_n}}q_n. Iterating this process, we may find states q_i\in S_{i} such that we have a sequence of transitions q_{i-1}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {a_i}}q_i in M; thus we have a sequence of transitions q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}}q_n. Because q_0\in S_0=s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}, we have s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q_0 and thus s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {\epsilon }}q_0\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}}q_n and therefore s_{M}\mathrel {\xRightarrow {u}} q_n. Because q_n\in F_{M}, we are done.

Let M be an NFA\varepsilon ; then \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\subseteq \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

We must show that any string u\in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} lies in \mathcal {L}{\mathopen {}\left (\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}\right )\mathclose {}}.

If u=\epsilon , then we have assumed that s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }q such that q\in F_{M}; therefore, by definition, we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus we have q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\cap F_{M} and so it follows by definition that s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}.
Suppose that u=a_1\cdots a_n, and so we have transitions s_{M}\xRightarrow {a_1}q_1\xRightarrow {\cdots } q_{n-1}\xRightarrow {a_n}q_n with q_n\in F_{M}.
We inductively define a sequence of states S_i in \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} as follows:
Define q_0=s_{M}. Then for all 0\leq i \leq n, we observe that we have q_i\in S_i.

We proceed by induction on i. For i=0, we need s_{M}\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}; but this holds by definition. Next, assuming q_i\in S_i we must show that q_{i+1}\in S_{i+1} = \delta _{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}{\mathopen {}\left (S_i,a_{i+1}\right )\mathclose {}}. Unfolding definitions, this follows from the transition q_i\xRightarrow {a_{i+1}} q_{i+1} that we have assumed, as our inductive hypothesis ensures q_i\in S_i.

It follows from the above that we have transitions S_0=s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\xrightarrow {a_1}S_1\xrightarrow {\cdots }S_{n-1}\xrightarrow {a_n}S_n. Becuase we have shown q_n\in S_n and we have assumed q_n\in F_{M}, we have S_n\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}. Thus it follows that \mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}} accepts u.

fr:title.text: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Equivalence between NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs

fr:mainmatter.html:p: NFA\varepsilon s, NFAs, and DFAs all generate the same class of languages.

In Lemma and Lemma , we have proved that NFA\varepsilon s and DFAs generate the same class of language as any NFA\varepsilon can be converted into a DFA recognising the same language. As any NFA is in particular an NFA\varepsilon , we see that NFAs are equivalent to DFAs in the same sense.
Why can’t we define F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} to be the set of singletons {\mathopen {}\left \{q\right \}\mathclose {}} such that q\in F_{M}?

Because if we did, then Lemma would fail already in the case of the empty string. We would have s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }{q} with q\in F_{M} and thus q\in s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}; we would need s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}}\in F_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} and with the proposed definition, this would need to be a singleton. There is, however, nothing about our assumptions that allows us to deduce that and, indeed, we can certainly come up with examples where s_{\mathcal {P}{\mathopen {}\left (M\right )\mathclose {}}} is not a singleton (e.g. if we have \epsilon -transitions of the form s_{M}\xRightarrow {\epsilon }q for q\not = s_{M}).
